Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Route up N side of Tiger Pk with Izzy. Surface hoar on surface, seen near ridgetop and some N aspects, ave. 4mm. Some 1mm (average) Rounding facets near both 12/7 and 12/20 rain crusts. Dug this and 3 additional quick pits on N-NW, NE, E aspects. And quick look at southerly aspect - number more melt freeze/sun crusts and noticeably shallower snowpack. Late Nov. SH not found here but was found nearby on same northerly aspect, ECTX.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Near treeline location with scoured surface (1cm rain crust). Many crusts and melt forms in upper snowpack sandwiched by melt forms. Most stout crust is 1cm thick ice crust at 148cm, with 3cm melt/freeze crust above and below. Below this Melt Freeze crust found shallow layer of small rounding facets. Difficult to disturb with thick crusts above, but had a broken CT29 on this layer. Did not dig past 40cm to ground.
Wind effect observed at all elevations. Snowpack is still thin and aspect-dependent.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: This area did not receive as much early season snow and is absent of melt freeze crust sandwiches, unlike the cottonwoods. The new snow that fell 12/23 measured about 4 inches, but drifted up to a foot in spots. Small localized cracking around the foot in shallower drifts but appeared to be fairly non-reactive.
Scoured open ridge with low HS. On flank of Path ET19.4. Representative of entire upper SZ which has very thin snow cover of 20-60 cm.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug by: Griffin Dittmar and Keith Kohlberg inside ski area boundary within terrain that has not been open yet for the season.
No collapsing, no cracking. Winds were gusty at times made it difficult to get an accurate size of SH(69-68.5cm) due to wind blowing crystals off card.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Johanna Kelly

Pit dug on a steep slope (41°) on a due north facing slope. Structure was poor GCS of 3 although stability (using triggered avalanches) was good as in we haven't heard of a natural avalanche into the PWL since December 9th. One explosive triggered slide into the PWL on PC Ridgeline on the 21st. If we went by stability results then stability would still be Poor-perhaps we look at the Stability scale (G.4 in SWAG) as it is mis-leading depending on how you use it.
I was unable to see or feel the layer within the newer snow approx. 25cm down from the surface that failed in two Compression Tests as well as in a Shovel Tilt Test.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit score 6 (out of 9) Layer 27-26: top is a 2mm ice lens with F hardness facets below it from 26-23.
Difficult to detect a hardness change between the upper ice lens and adjacent rounds.

November facets still very reactive and contributing to poor structure.
Grom score 4 (our of 9)

Pit_Observation.activities: Collapsing, localized; Cracking;

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Very crusty below 8300ft, turning to dense pow up higher. This was probably one of the less stable areas in the past week of pits. It would seem that more snow/weight could bump up the chance of an avalance in certain areas of this bowl. Also, the PWL in this area is only 60cms below the surface.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Presencia de efectos de lluvia en el manto. Correspondientes aproximadamente a la semana del 5 al 12 de Diciembre.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: With a green light and no instability seen in the drainage over multiple days, we decided to skin up, dig a pit, and ride Barrieto in Mineral Fork. The snow was variable with a mix of dense pow, wind skin, shallow wind drifts, and firm wind crust with graupel on top. It was warm down low, but above 8500ft the snow was still cold and dry. The faceting thats taken place on the top layer of snow is reactive to wind loading

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Pit dug in a talus field with very uneven ground surface - unable to cut ECT or PST due to large talus. Area also subject to wind loading.

Pit_Observation.activities: Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: An old size 1 or 2 avalanche was observed higher up near the saddle at about 3150m that ran on an E aspect. Signs of perhaps cross slope wind loading on the E face of Sadzele West Peak
Overall, a right-side-up snowpack. Two feet of new snow on top of the old snow interface. Planer bed surface at interface. No defined weak layer to hold energy.

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Weekly Sunshine Snow Safety Full Profile. On stability compression tests, 1 out of 3 produced CTH 23 SC @ 5 cm off ground in Depth Hoar layer. The collapse was on the saw and was not reproduced in any other tests.
Pretty thin and pretty weak

Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Hyvin luultavasti kelkan aiheuttama kaukolaukaisu klo 11-17 välillä. Vyöryn leveys noin 100 m. Pysähtyi kurun pohjalle. Kruunu paksuimmillaan 2 metriä. Murtuma levisi huomattavasti laajemmalle alueelle kuin mikä vyöryi. Yksi pienempi kasauma alempana kurussa.

Pit_Observation.activities: We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Wouldn't recommend riding here right now, but there is enough snow to become a problem in the future. On going faceting is weakening the surface layer.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry;
Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Winds were light to moderate from the SSW across the ridgelines. Calm down in the trees with increasing high thin clouds throughout the afternoon. Below 8k all aspects were wetted on the surface with increasing size of wet roller balls as elevation decreased to 7200'. They were up to 2' in diameter and breaking apart on east facing aspects in the trees.
Open Roll feature at Tree line.

Pit_Observation.activities: Cracking;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Slope is mostly sheltered from the wind. Wind drifting snow confined to lee of immediate ridgetop. Minimal snow is available for transport. Warm temps.
